item.title: Composable
item.description: The ability to freely combine smaller programmed artifacts into larger ones, to accomplish larger goals There exist building blocks which span a range of useful combinations.

item.title: Data changes the application
item.description: Existing large owners of data won’t innovate because they have monopoly over data, new innovators cant enter because they lack data

item.title: Fishbowl effect
item.description: Jonathan Zdziarski (aka @NerveGas) on user demands: “There is definitely a place for users and their demands, however that’s not inside the community (unless they’re also contributing devs); the community, as in practicing any art form, is vulnerable; you wouldn’t sit and criticize a painter while they’re still painting their piece.

item.title: Semilattice
item.description: Visualizing graphs The example the article used was to try and an orange, a watermelon, a football and a tennis ball.

item.title: Verisimilitude
item.description: Truth is not binary, but rather a spectrum. Some propositions are closer to being true than other propositions. Very related to the work of Karl Popper and his philosophy of science.

item.title: Agency
item.description: Agency is the ability and freedom for an individual to act in their immediate context or environment. See also: [[thoughts/Tools for Conviviality]], [[posts/agentic-computing|agentic computing]]

item.title: Easy is not always better
item.description: Are ’easy-to-use’ products always better? Interesting read about the ‘seductive, destructive appeal of ease of use’: the belief that “ease of use” is somehow conflated with better products.

item.title: OODA
item.description: OODA stands for observe, orient, decide, act. Initially developed by a military strategist, it is now applied to understand commercial operations and [[thoughts/information behaviour]]

item.title: Map as territory
item.description: “Our maps are still maps, approximating the landscape of truth from the territories of the knowable — incomplete representational models that always leave more to map, more to fathom, because the selfsame forces that made the universe also made the figuring instrument with which we try to comprehend it.

item.title: Attention
item.description: Attention is the stuff of manifestation. In the same way that looking at something while you’re driving takes you there, paying attention to anything (a field, an attitude, a person), will drive you uncontrollably toward it.

item.title: Self-directed Growth
item.description: See also: [[posts/the-fools-who-dream]], [[thoughts/independent research]] How do we give the tools to people so learn for themselves? To treat growth as if it was play?

item.title: Taste
item.description: ![[thoughts/images/developing taste.png]] Taste is built over time through repeated applications. It requires intention, focus, and care. Taste is a commitment to a state of [[thoughts/attention|attention]].

item.title: Overlay Network
item.description: A network that is layered on top of another network Normally on top of [[thoughts/HTTP]]. Fun fact! The [[thoughts/Internet]] was originally built as an overlay upon the telephone network

item.title: Postel's Law
item.description: Be conservative in what you send, be liberal in what you accept The principle is also known as Postel’s law, after Jon Postel, who used the wording in an early specification of [[thoughts/TCP]].

item.title: Risk Homeostasis
item.description: When seatbelts were made mandatory, the number of deaths on the road actually didn’t decrease, they stayed roughly the same!

item.title: 50 pounds of pots
item.description: Quantity is the journey to quality The ceramics teacher announced on opening day that he was dividing the class into two groups.

item.title: r/K Selection theory
item.description: In ecology, r/K selection theory relates to the selection of combinations of traits in an organism that trade off between quantity and quality of offspring

item.description: One sub-branch of the Exit, Voice, and Loyalty model (based on [[thoughts/game theory|game theory]]). Exit, Voice, and Loyalty There are two agents.

item.title: Inevitability of Recentralization
item.description: Notes on Gordon Brander’s Decentralization enables permissionless innovation, Centralization is Inevitable and Redecentralization To be efficient is to be fragile, and to be fragile, over the long run, is to go extinct.

item.title: Neutrality
item.description: Net Neutrality The Neutrality Pyramid: A Policy Framework to Distribute Power Over the Net by Juan Ortiz Freuler Neutrality: “It is fundamental to our right to freedom of expression that any and all parties who exercise control over any layer of our channels of communication respect the integrity of the message that is being delivered.

item.title: Collaborative software
item.description: Each user device has a local replica of the data and this local replica can be updated anytime (ideally even while offline), and re-sync with others when network is available

item.title: Local-first software
item.description: By centralizing data storage on servers, cloud apps also take away ownership and agency from users. If a service shuts down, the software stops functioning, and data created with that software is lost.

item.title: Personal and cozy software
item.description: cozy eternal beta test mode Not everything needs to be built at scale – sometimes it can just be for family and friends :)) Normalize creating playful and non- instrumental technology

item.title: Chesterton's Fence
item.description: “Don’t ever take a fence down until you truly know the reason why it was put up” – G.K. Chesterton

item.title: Desire path
item.description: The path usually represents the shortest or most easily navigated route between an origin and destination. The width and severity of erosion are often indicators of the traffic level that a path receives.

item.title: Constructionism
item.description: “As children construct things in the world, they construct new ideas and theories in their minds, which motivates them to construct new things in the world, and on and on.

item.title: Crutch and Shoe metaphor
item.description: Those with broken legs will use crutches. Shoes however, will enhance performance no matter what.

item.title: Goodhart's Law
item.description: “When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure” – [Goodhart’s Law] “When quantifying things, people naturally focus on things that can easily be measured.

item.title: Potemkin villages
item.description: A “Potemkin village” signifies any deceptive or false construct, conjured often by cruel regimes, to deceive both those within the land and those peering in from outside.

item.title: Stone Soup metaphor
item.description: Stone Soup Metaphor Source: Stone Soup in Wikipedia Some travelers come to a village, carrying nothing more than an empty cooking pot.

item.title: Collingridge Dilemma
item.description: Efforts to influence or control the further development of technology face a [[thoughts/catch 22|double-bind]] problem An information problem: impacts cannot be easily predicted until the technology is extensively developed and widely used.

item.title: Maintenance
item.description: Maintenance: the gritty upkeep work that keeps the infrastructure of the world running. One of my favourite examples is the constant rebuilding of the Ise Grand Shrine.

item.title: Skyhooks
item.description: We should have nondystopian science fiction – there’s value in reclaiming an optimistic and hopeful future. I love the concept of skyhooks: dream about what you can build as if the sky had hooks you could hang your creations from (a metaphor for unlimited resources) and most of the time, you can still create that with scarce resources.

item.title: Vanilla Ice Cream effect
item.description: Ask everyone to vote on their favourite ice cream, you’ll most likely end up with vanilla. Similar to design by committee: a project that has many designers involved but no unifying plan or vision

item.title: Linguistic Relativism
item.description: See: [[thoughts/language|linguistics]] Does language dictate how we think about the world? Do we need labels and terminology to discuss things? Yes!

item.title: Interoperability
item.description: Portability implies switching platforms, but true interoperability is platform-agnostic. I think interoperability in the context of the web means being able to transparently understand and share data, agnostic of platform.

item.description: by Langdon Winner “Politics” is defined as “arrangements of power and authority in human associations as well as the activities that take place within those arrangements.

item.title: Lindy Effect
item.description: Lindy Effect: future life expectancy of a bit of technology is proportional to its current age (i.e. the longer something has survived, the more likely it is to have a longer remaining life expectancy).

item.description: Related: games Game Design and Teaching Source: Game designers vs. education researchers on unguided instruction by Andy Matuschak A mistake we made early on was looking primarily at metrics like retention and monetization.

item.title: Fiction
item.description: The future is manifested Shared fiction as a statement about the future instead of a statement of today. They’re both fictions in that they can’t be (dis)proved and thus can have the same functions in a group of people (bring together, motivate to action, share values/[[thoughts/language|language]], etc.

item.description: The more accessible a good is, the less people want to pay for it. – Scott Moore A government only has interest in funding its own roads, companies like Facebook only have interest in funding their own infrastructure.

item.title: Multiple Realization
item.description: Are there multiple ways of realizing intelligence? The bitter lesson: the less human heuristics we insert and the more we improve the learning capacity of the network, the better they seem to perform.

item.title: Labels, quantization, and legibility
item.description: “Legibility is a condition of manipulation. Any substantial state intervention in society – to vaccinate a population, produce goods, mobilize labour, tax people and their property, conduct literacy campaigns, conscript soldiers, enforce sanitation standards, catch criminals start universal schooling – requires the invention of units that are visible”
